sentence: In view of rising healthcare costs, the world's largest retailer Wal-Mart Stores Inc. ( WMT ) announced that it would increase the health insurance premiums for its U.S. employees.
Also, the retailer plans to eliminate health insurance coverage for some of its part-time U.S. workers.
Starting from Jan 1, Walmart will raise premiums for all its full-time and part-time workers to counter rising healthcare costs.
For a basic plan, the premiums will increase to $21.90 per pay period, up from $18.40 for the enrolled workers, per The Associated Press.
The decision will be harsh on the employees' pockets as the company will also lower the percentage of the bill it will cover for doctor visits, tests and other services to 75% from 80%.
In addition, it will not offer health insurance to employees who work less than an average of 30 hours a week.
The move will impact around 30,000 U.S. employees.
Like Walmart, other retailers like Target Corp. ( TGT ) and The Home Depot, Inc. ( HD ) have also cut down on health insurance benefits for part-time employees.
This is not the first time that Walmart has cut back the healthcare benefits for its workers.
In 2011, the retailer had eliminated healthcare coverage for part-timers who were working less than 24 hours a week.
The news came a day after Walmart teamed up with DirectHealth.com, an online health insurance agency to help customers understand more about health insurance plans.
(Read: Walmart to Educate Shoppers on Health Insurance Options ).
But Walmart had to take this tough decision following rollout of The U.S.
Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, known as Obamacare, which requires big companies to offer coverage to employees working 30 hours or more a week, or face a penalty.
Walmart also stated during the second quarter of fiscal 2015 in August that more and more U.S. employees and their families are enrolling in its healthcare plans than it had expected.
The medical cost inflation and increased healthcare enrollments in the U.S. have increased the healthcare costs of the company.
It has thus raised its estimate for U.S. healthcare costs this year to $500 million from $330 million, previously anticipated.
In response, the company has also lowered its earnings guidance for fiscal 2015.
Walmart holds a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold).
A better-ranked retailer worth considering is Citi Trends, Inc. ( CTRN ), sporting a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy).
